prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2O 658 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of the H2O nu2=1 1_1,0 - 1_0,1 line at 658 GHz in IRC+10216. One spectral window will cover this H2O line (+ C18O J=6-5), the other spectral windows will cover the 13CO J=6-5, the 13C17O J=6-5, and the SiO v=1 J=15-14 line

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have selected spectral windows of 1875 MHz and a resolution of 0.9 km/s (spectral smoothing of a factor 4).
1. Spectral resolution elements The terminal wind velocity of CW Leo is 15 km/s; however, the vibrationally excited H2O line is formed in the wind acceleration region close to the stellar surface, where the wind has not yet reached its full terminal velocity. We therefore expect that the total line width of the H2O line to be 10-15 km/s (see Fig. 5b in Decin et al. 2015, A&A 574, A5). To have enough spectral data points to properly recover the line profile, we allow for a spectral smoothing of a factor of 4 (i.e. spectral resolution of 0.9 km/s).
2. Bandwidths The wide bandwidths were chosen to maximize the possibilities for serendipitous discoveries of other line features. The line-free region will be used to image the dust continuum around IRC+10216.
Although the primary science goal of this investigation is the study of water vapor in IRC+10216, the large bandwidth of ALMA will enable a number of secondary science projects (see the section on 'Paralle science goals' in the 'Science Case'). Through a judicious choice of correlator setup (which does not in any way impact the quality of the data we will obtain on water), we will simultaneously observe the C18O J = 6-5 (658.553 GHz) in the same spectral window as the H2O 110-101 2=1line (658.007 GHz). The other 3 spectral windows cover the 13CO J= 6-5 transition (661.067 GHz), the 13C17O J= 6-5 transition (643.600 GHz), and the 28Si16O v=1 J=15-14 transition (646.429 GHz). Other spectral features in the envisioned SPWs include transitions of SiO and SiS (and their isotopologues), SiC2, AlF, 13CS, etc (see Decin et al. 2015). We request the same correlator setup as for our Cycle 0 data, since the quality of the Cycle 0 data was limited due to the sparse visibility plane coverage and high rms noise. The Cycle 3 data will enable us to have a better (u,v) coverage and to detect (amongst other features) the 13C17O J=6-5 line (see main proposal text).
The broad bandwith allows a good continuum sensitivity (see previous box) which will enable us to study the dust, to self-calibrate, to subtract the continuum and to obtain accurate spectral baselines.
We note that we have entered a frequency of 646.129 GHz instead of the actualy frequency of 646.429 GHz for the SiO line in baseband 2 in order to avoid lines exactly overlapping from the mirror sideband, in all sidebands. If a different shift is advised when the SBs are prepared, please advise.

We request a spatial resolution of 0.1" to spatially resolve the water formation region. The source of vibrationally excited H2O line emission is expected to be compact, with the line emission confined to a region of size <0.4" (=20 stellar radii) in diameter. With the requested angular resolution, we will resolve the emission down to ~2.5 stellar radii (in radius) or place very tight constraints on the extent of the excitation region if it is unresolved. The dust condensation region has a size of ~0.2" in diameter and could hence not be resolved with our Cycle 0 data (spatial resolution of 0.23", Decin et al. 2015). With an angular resolution of 0.1", we will resolve this dust condensation region and it will be possible to accurately determine the stellar and dust contribution in the continuum measurements (as obtained from the line-free regions) allowing a detailed assessment of the total dust mass.
The requested LAS of 1" is smaller than the largest recoverable angular scale and hence ACA is not required. Following the results of our Cycle 0 data and the IR interferometry images by Weigelt et al. (2002), it might well be that the H2O emission is clumped as well, with clump sizes around 100-300 mas (< requested LAS). However, to trace the H2O and dust morphology also at larger spatial scales, we request a LAS of 1".

1. Requested line sensitivity and spectral resolution
In order to achieve - for either water production scenario - an expected signal-to-noise ratio > 5 on the 658 GHz water line (in a 1 km/s channel), we require a sensitivity of 12 mJy. The terminal wind velocity of CW Leo is 15 km/s; however, the vibrationally excited H2O line is formed in the wind acceleration region close to the stellar surface, where the wind has not yet reached its full terminal velocity. We therefore expect that the total line width of the H2O line to be 10-15 km/s (see Fig. 5b in Decin et al. 2015, A&A 574, A5). To have enough spectral data points to properly recover the line profile, we allow for a spectral smoothing of a factor of 4 (i.e. spectral resolution of 0.9 km/s) and ask the requested sensitivity of 12 mJy/beam to be reached within 1 km/s spectral channels.
According to the OT sensitivity calculator, the required time is 3.12 hr on source, or 6.93 hr including all overheads.
2. Reached RMS for the continuum observations
The achieved rms over the total 7.5 GHz bandwidth is ~0.2 mJy/beam. Assuming a 3GHz line-free continuum, the expected continuum rms noise is ~0.3 mJy/beam. The Cycle 0 continuum image of CW Leo and the surrounding dust had a continuum peak of 4.362 Jy/beam (for a beam of 0.24x0.42") and noise rms of 5 mJy/beam. The (unresolved) stellar contribution is around 2.3 Jy (see Decin et al. 2015). The ALMA Cycle 0 could barely detect the spiral arcs/clumps present beyond 0.5" due to the limitations in continuum sensitivity. The Cycle 3 data will have a noise sensitivity which is at least a factor of 17 better which should allow us to track the detailed dust morphology up to at least 2" in the inner wind allowing us to determine if the dust and gas are co-spatial within the spiral arcs/clumps. The brightness of the continuum makes it possible to self-calibrate on the source, which will improve the accuracy of the determination of the extent of the water excitation region. Phase referencing would be helpful for astrometry, gain calibration and to determine the significant extended continuum component.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the highlights of Herschel was the discovery of water vapor in the warm inner envelope of the carbon-rich Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) star IRC+10216. The derived water abundance is several orders of magnitude larger than the photospheric abundance expected under thermochemical equilibrium. This huge discrepancy had led to the suggestions of several possible origins for the water vapor. Only two, still competing, theories are consistent with the existence of warm water vapor: (1) the photochemistry model within a clumpy outflow, and (2) non-equilibrium chemistry associated with pulsationally-driven shock waves. However, Herschel lacked the spatial resolution needed to probe the very innermost regions of the outflow where the two competing models predict different spatial profiles. Currently, only ALMA can provide us with high enough a sensitivity and spatial resolution to discriminate between the two alternative explanations. We propose to observe the vibrationally-excited water at 658 GHz. Making the first image of water in the envelope of a carbon-rich giant will show the impact of ALMA on our understanding of the physics and chemistry going on in evolved stars.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals:
* 2011.1.00277.S: ALMA Cycle 0 proposal on this topic, rank `highest priority' rating (top 10%) . Only 1 OB obtained; noise was factor 7 worse than requested for which reason the study on the water vapour content could not be pursued. The Cycle 0 data have been published (Decin et al. 2015, A&A 574, A5) demonstrating the strength of ALMA 13CO J=6-5 data to understand the complex morphology in the inner wind of CW Leo.
* 2012-1.00324.S: ALMA Cycle 1 proposal on this topic; resubmission of proposal 2011.1.00277.S, rank: `highest priority' rating (top 10%) - no data obtained. Proposal transfered to Cycle 2 - no data obtained yet
